column1: Senta (Serbian Cyrillic: Сента (pronounced [sɛ̌ːnta]); Hungarian: Zenta (pronounced [ˈzɛntɒ]); Romanian: Zenta) is a town and municipality located in the North Banat District of the autonomous province of Vojvodina
column2: Serbia. It is situated on the bank of the Tisa river in the geographical region of Bačka. The town has a population of 18

column1: Archaeological finds indicate that the area around the modern settlement was populated from the prehistoric times. Neolithic and eneolithic societies settled in the vicinity of modern Senta thousands of years ago leaving credible traces of their presence. A Neolithic Tiszapolgár–Bodrogkeresztúr culture necropolis was found in Senta. The first historic population that might have lived in the area were most likely the Agathyrsi (6th century BC). With certainty we can claim that the inhabitants of the early "Senta" in the 6th century AD were Sarmatians
column2: Slavs alike and Avars. Hungarian people invaded the area during the great breakthrough of the Magyars in the 9th century AD.
the town was mentioned first in 1216 under the name Szintarev. In this time
column3: it was under administration of the medieval Kingdom of Hungary. The entire area was sacked by Mongols in 1241/42. After initial salvation
column4: Senta saw more than two centuries of prosperity. Initially
column5: the town was part of Bodrog county
column6: but from 1246 it was part of the Csanad County
column7: and later part of the Csongrád County. Records also indicate that from the year 1440 an area south of Senta called Peser was under the control of the Serbian despots. In the second half of the 15th century there occurred a brief conflict
column9: with the rivaling community of Szeged. Nevertheless
column10: in the year 1506 Senta became a royal free city
column11: granted that by the Czech–Hungarian King Vladislav II Jagellion. By that time Senta had a fort
column12: a harbour and a catholic monastery. The peasant rebellions of 1514 did not include Senta in the wake of destruction. Although still under administration of the Kingdom of Hungary in 1525 there was an autonomous Serb militia stationed in the fort. Autonomous in terms of command since on the list of officers one can clearly note that Serb units had their own commanding officers
column13: most notably Mihailo Konjović and Stevan Brančić. After the Battle of Mohács in 1526 Senta was no longer under administration of the Kingdom of Hungary. In the brief period of the reign of Serb Emperor Jovan Nenad
column14: Senta was part of Jovan Nenad's state and was a refuge for Serb forces. One may clearly acknowledge this due to the fact that after being seriously wounded in Szeged
column15: Jovan Nenad and his guards retreated towards Senta
column16: only to be intercepted by Hungarian forces and murdered in the village of Tornjoš. After Jovan Nenad was murdered and his state collapsed
column17: Senta was again placed under administration of the Kingdom of Hungary
column18: until it came under full Ottoman control in 1542. During Ottoman conquest
column19: local Hungarian population left this area
column20: which was then populated by Serbs who came from other parts of the Ottoman Empire.During the second half of the 16th century and most of the 17th century Senta was under administration of the Ottoman Empire and the town and area were part of the Sanjak of Segedin. However
column21: Ottomans only operated a garrison in the fort
column22: while the population of settlement was Serb. The reputed traveler
column25: and noted that it is a small place
column26: quiet and calm with a fort
column27: a mosque and a village with enough services to maintain itself. On the 15. October 1686 a skirmish between local Serb insurgence under Habsburg command and a smaller Ottoman force occurred. The event is known as the First Battle of Senta. From the year 1686 to the more commonly known Battle of Senta in 1697 the town and its surroundings were no longer under Ottoman control
column28: but at the same time were neither controlled by the Habsburgs.

column1: On 11 September 1697 Prince Eugene of Savoy defeated the Ottoman army in the Battle of Senta
column2: which was fought at this location
column3: and after the Treaty of Karlovci in 1699
column4: the town was included into Habsburg Monarchy as part of the Tisza–Maros section of the Military Frontier. Amongst those involved in the battle was skilled Serb officer
column5: Captain and later Colonel Jovan Popović Tekelija
column6: who after the conflict took command over part of the Frontier. During this period Senta was mainly populated by Serbs and had a small Orthodox church. It was well fortified and protected by organized units of Serb militia called Frontiersmen. After the abolishment of this part of the Frontier in 1751
column7: Senta was included into District of Theiss
column8: which was part of the Bács-Bodrog County of the Habsburg Kingdom of Hungary. Many of the Serbs that lived in the town
column9: and that now considered themselves humiliated by being reduced from soldiers to farmers
column10: emigrated either to other parts of the Habsburg Monarchy where Military Frontier was still needed either to Russia (notably to New Serbia and Slavo-Serbia). One of the settlements in New Serbia was also named Senta by the Serb colonists.

column5: and Jews settled in the town. In 1848–1849 revolution
column6: the town was alternately controlled by the forces of the Kingdom of Hungary and forces of the Serbian Vojvodina. From 1849 to 1860
column7: it was part of the Voivodeship of Serbia and Banat of Temeschwar
column8: a separate Austrian crown land. After abolishment of the voivodeship in 1860
column9: Senta was again included into Bács-Bodrog County. In 1910
column10: the population of the town numbered 29

column1: Serbs started to settle in the town in larger number again after the First World War
column2: when Senta became part of the Kingdom of Serbs
column3: Croats and Slovenes (later renamed to Yugoslavia) in 1918. From 1918 to 1922
column4: the town was part of Novi Sad County
column5: from 1922 to 1929 part of Belgrade Oblast
column6: and from 1929 to 1941 part of Danube Banovina. From 1941 to 1944
column7: Senta was occupied by the Axis troops and was attached to Horthy's Hungary. After the war
column9: Senta became part of the Autonomous Province of Vojvodina within new socialist Yugoslavia. From 1945 Vojvodina was part of the People's Republic of Serbia within Yugoslavia.
